segments.text:
Outline
1. RAG basics
2. Retriever options
3. Graph RAG
4. Evaluation
Graph RAG pipeline
We combine event graphs with retrieval. Components are:
- Document parsing
- Event extraction
- Graph construction
- Indexing and query planning:
- 1) Retrieve nodes/edges relevant to the query
- 2) Expand neighborhoods to capture context
- 3) Rank subgraphs and select top-K,
- 4) Compose context for the generator

References
- Lewis et al. (RAG)
- Raft et al. (Domain-specific RAG fine-tuning)
- Recent benchmarks and datasets

Reactive Ion Etching (RIE) Overview
- Purpose: anisotropic etching for microfabrication
- Typical materials: Si, SiO2, Si3N4
- We compare selectivity, profile control, and damage
Process parameters (RIE):
- Gas mixture: SF6/O2 (selectivity to Si vs SiO2 depends on O2%)
- Power: RF bias controls ion energy,
- Pressure: 5–30 mTorr; affects mean free path
- Temperature: 10–30°C (chuck cooling)
- Notes: polymer formation and sidewall passivation
• Power tuning impacts ion-assisted chemical etching; higher bias increases anisotropy
• Lower pressure increases directionality; too low reduces radical density
• Etch profile control: sidewall passivation via O radicals—

Summary
- RIE combines chemical etching and physical sputtering
- Gas chemistry determines selectivity
- RF power and pressure balance anisotropy vs damage
Case study: SF6/O2 ratio vs Si/SiO2 selectivity
Figure 2. Etch rate (nm/min) vs O2% at 10 mTorr, 200 W. As O2 increases, Si etch rate first rises then falls due to passivation. Observed knee near 25% O2:
Figure 2 (cont.) Etch rate vs O2% shows optimum selectivity near 20–25% O2 with stable profiles. Beyond 35%, excessive passivation reduces etch and causes micro-masking.
